children.name: react
children.definition: to behave in a particular way or show a particular emotion because of something that has happened or been said : phản ứng
examples: How did your parents react when you told them you were going to marry Jim?
It’s hard not to react badly when your kids are playing up.

children.name: react badly
children.definition: become annoyed, upset etc
examples: Do you react badly to criticism?

children.name: react angrily/violently
examples: The Prime Minister reacted angrily to these accusations.

children.name: react strongly
examples: Scott reacted strongly when he felt he was being treated unjustly.

children.name: react quickly/swiftly
examples: The goalkeeper had to react quickly.

children.name: react differently
examples: People react differently to stress.

children.name: react positively/negatively
children.definition: with positive/negative emotions or opinions
examples: We want versatile people who react positively to change.

children.name: react cautiously
children.definition: carefully, so that you avoid danger or risk
examples: The United States has reacted cautiously to the offer.

children.name: react instinctively
children.definition: without thinking or needing to think
examples: She reacted instinctively and reached for her gun.

children.name: react to
examples: How did Wilson react to your idea?

children.name: react against
examples: Emma is not behaving very reasonably nowadays. I think she’s reacting against her teachers’ strictness.

children.name: react by doing sth
examples: The government reacted by declaring all strikes illegal.

children.name: react with disappointment/laughter/violence etc
examples: When children perform poorly at school, parents often react with anger.
Many gays reacted with outrage at the tactic of ‘outing’ senior public figures.

children.name: react against sthphrasal verb
examples: to show that you dislike someone else’s ideas or ways of doing something, by deliberately doing the opposite :
Hereacted stronglyagainst his religious upbringing.

children.name: respond
children.definition: to react to something that someone has said to you, or something that someone has done to you or for you: đáp lại, đáp trả
examples: The more attention you pay him, the better he responds.

children.name: respond to
examples: Responding to the news, Mr Watt appealed for calm.
The children responded well to the day’s activities.
The theatre has been slow to respond to the challenges presented by progressive drama.

children.name: respond with
examples: Villagers responded with offers of help.
Rob’s smile was irresistible, and she responded with a grin.

children.name: respond by doing sth
examples: The US responded by sending troops into Laos.
The demonstrators attacked and burned buildings and cars; the soldiers responded by opening fire.

children.name: greet
children.definition: to react to something with a particular attitude or with a particular action: đón nhận, chào đón
examples: The news has been greeted angrily within Egyptian government circles.

children.name: be greeted with/by sth
examples: His statement was greeted with cries of astonishment and indignation.
Donaldson’s remarks were greeted with cautious enthusiasm.
The proposals were greeted with a mixture of skepticism and distrust.

children.name: meet with
children.definition: to get a particular reaction, especially a negative one: nhận được
examples: The proposals met with fierce opposition from women’s groups and labour unions.
Any attempts to impose a solution would be quite likely to meet with even more violence.
At the time the decision was met with a barrage of criticism.

children.name: meet with sb’s approval
examples: I trust the arrangements meet with your approval .

children.name: to be met with
examples: The US says any further attacks will be met with the full force of the US military.

children.name: overreact
children.definition: to react to something with too much emotion, or by doing something that is unnecessary : phản ứng dữ dội
examples: Don’t you think you’re overreacting? I only said ‘hi’. It’s not as if we’re having an affair!
overreact to
You always overreact to criticism.
Many investors overreacted to the stock market crash.
overreact with
Overreacting with shock when a child uses a swear word is likely to make him use it again
overreaction[ singular, uncountable ] :
Their response was an overreaction.

children.name: recieve
children.definition: receive to react in a particular way to a suggestion, idea, performance etc
examples: He received the news in silence.
well/ warmly/ coldly etc received
The film waswell receivedby critics
The prime minister's speech was warmly received by the conference delegates.

children.name: what sb says or does when they react to sth
reaction
children.definition: sth that you feel, say, or do because of sth that has happened or been said :
examples: What was Jeff’s reaction when you told him about the job?
reaction to/ against
the government’s reaction to the fuel crisis
in reaction to sth
An emergency fund was set up in reaction to the famine.

children.name: sb’s first/initial/immediate reaction
examples: His first reaction was to laugh.

children.name: sb’s gut reactioninformal
children.definition: what they feel or decide immediately, before thinking
examples: You must trust your gut reactions.

children.name: sb’s instinctive reaction
children.definition: what they do immediately, before thinking
examples: Often your instinctive reaction is to blame someone else.

children.name: a natural reaction
examples: Anger is a natural reaction if you feel undervalued.

children.name: a knee-jerk reaction
children.definition: an immediate reaction that happens without sensible thinking
examples: Environmentalists have a knee-jerk reaction against any development.

children.name: an emotional reaction
children.definition: showing strong emotion, especially by crying
examples: I was surprised by her emotional reaction to the news.

children.name: a positive/favourable reaction
children.definition: showing that someone agrees or likes something
examples: There has been a positive reaction to the campaign.

children.name: a negative reaction
children.definition: showing that someone disagrees or dislikes something
examples: We are concerned about the negative reaction of some of our customers.

children.name: mixed reactions
children.definition: some positive and some negative reactions
examples: The book met with mixed reactions.

children.name: a violent/angry reaction
examples: The artists were surprised by the violent reactions to their work.

children.name: a delayed reaction
children.definition: a reaction that comes some time after an event
examples: You’re suffering a delayed reaction to the accident.

children.name: the public reaction
children.definition: what the public think about something that happens
examples: The public reaction was less than encouraging.

children.name: provoke/produce/bring a reaction
examples: The decision provoked an angry reaction from the local tourist industry.

children.name: get a reaction
examples: We didn’t know what kind of reaction we would get.

children.name: gauge sb’s reaction
children.definition: judge or find out someone’s reaction
examples: He watched Jane’s face, trying to gauge her reaction.

children.name: judging by sb’s reactions
examples: Judging by the audience’s reactions, the show will be a great success.

children.name: response
children.definition: something that is done as a reaction to sth that has happened or been said
examples: response to
the public’s response to our appeal for help
in response to sth
The law was passed in response to public pressure.

children.name: a positive/favourable response
examples: The product met with a highly positive response from the public.

children.name: a negative response
examples: In Russia, the planned expansion provoked a negative response.

children.name: an enthusiastic response
examples: There has been an enthusiastic response to the introduction of soccer coaching for girls.

children.name: an angry response
examples: His comments sparked an angry response from opposition politicians.

children.name: a good/encouraging response
children.definition: when people like something or show interest
examples: We’ve had a good response from the public.

children.name: sb’s immediate response
examples: When he was sentenced, his immediate response was to appeal.

children.name: a direct response
examples: Her resignation was in direct response to the party’s poor results in the local elections.

children.name: an appropriate response
examples: She laughed, which didn't really seem an appropriate response.

children.name: a strong response
examples: The photograph provoked a strong response from many people.

children.name: an emotional response
examples: When she died, the emotional response was extraordinary.

children.name: get a positive etc response
examples: She got an enthusiastic response to her suggestion.

children.name: receive a positive etc response
children.definition: get it
examples: The proposal has received a positive response from most left-wing voters.

children.name: meet with a positive etc response
children.definition: get it
examples: The change met with a mixed response from employees.

children.name: provoke a response
examples: The report provoked a strong response from a number of senior politicians.

children.name: draw/bring a response from somebody
examples: The appeal for aid brought a big response from the West.

children.name: feedback
children.definition: advice, criticism, praise etc that you give to sb, telling them how well they are working:phản hồi
examples: ▪ We are very encouraged by the feedback we’ve had from our shareholders.
Have youhadany feedbackfromcustomers about the new soap?
feed back[verb not in progressive]: phản hồi
▪ Regular reports are fed back to senior managers.

children.name: give sb feedback/give feedback (to sb)
examples: ▪ Every Friday, Mr James would hand out the students’ essays and give them some feedback.

children.name: feedback on: phản hồi về
examples: ▪ It is important to give employees regular feedback on their performance.

children.name: positive/negative feedback
examples: ▪ I’m lucky to work for an employer who gives positive feedback on my work.

children.name: backlash
children.definition: an angry or violent reaction by a group of people to the actions or decisions of others: phản ứng dữ dội
examples: backlash against
▪ Members of the Rifle and Pistol Club fear a public backlash against their sport after a recent armed raid in the village.
▪ The attacks have sparked a bitter backlash against the revolutionary forces.
backlash from
▪a growing backlash from angry voters

children.name: overreaction
children.definition: when someone reacts much too strongly to something: phản ứng quá mức
examples: Their response was an overreaction.
▪ I’m not arguing in favor of cannabis. I’m just saying we should be careful of overreaction.
▪ The appeal court judge described the sentence as a gross overreaction to the recent spate of bombing campaigns.

children.name: reception
children.definition: a particular type of reaction to sb’s ideas, work etc – used especially in the following phrases : sự đón nhận, tiếp nhận
examples: She was unsure of her reception after everything that had happened.

children.name: a warm reception
children.definition: friendly or approving
examples: The Prince was given a warm reception when he visited Birmingham.

children.name: an enthusiastic/rapturous/rousing reception
children.definition: in which people show a lot of approval in a noisy way
examples: She received an enthusiastic reception.

children.name: a hostile reception
examples: When reporters arrived at the house, they got a hostile reception.

children.name: a cool/chilly/frosty reception
children.definition: not friendly or approving
examples: His idea got a cool reception from his colleagues.

children.name: a lukewarm reception
children.definition: not enthusiastic
examples: I am bewildered by the lukewarm reception given to her latest album.

children.name: a mixed reception
children.definition: when some people like something and some do not
examples: His first novel received a mixed reception.

children.name: a favourable/positive reception
examples: The movie got a favourable reception from audiences and critics alike.

children.name: get/have a warm etc reception
children.definition: alsoreceive a warm etc receptionformal
examples: As he came on, Rocky got a great reception from the crowd.

children.name: meet with a warm etc receptionformal
examples: They met with a chilly reception from my mother.

children.name: give somebody/something a warm etc reception
examples: Opposition parties gave the proposals a lukewarm reception.

children.name: receive/have/get/meet with a ... reception
examples: He got a great reception from the crowd.
The plans received amixed receptionfrom unions(= some people liked them, others did not ).

children.name: reactions
children.definition: sb’s ability to be able to react quickly to moving objects, danger etc: phản ứng, phản xạ
examples: Alcohol slows a driver’s reactions, making it harder to avoid an accident.
He was a natural boxer, with a cold temper, fast reactions and a killer instinct.

children.name: reflexes
children.definition: the natural ability to react quickly and well to dangers etc, without having to think about what you are doing: khả năng phản xạ
examples: Bernice moved to slap him, but with lightning reflexes, he grasped her arm.
City got only one goal, and owed everything to the extraordinarily quick reflexes of their goalkeeper.

children.name: sensitive
children.definition: easily affected or damaged by sth such as a substance or temperature : nhạy cảm
examples: Wetlands are environmentally sensitive areas.
a baby’s sensitive skin
sensitive to
Older people tend to be very sensitive to cold.
Increasing numbers of people are sensitive to cow’s milk.

children.name: alert
children.definition: adjective

children.name: quick to see, understand and act in a particular situation
examples: I'm not feeling very alert today - not enough sleep last night!
A couple of alert readers wrote in to the paper pointing out the mistake.
Parents should be alerttosudden changes in children's behaviour.

children.name: on your toes
children.definition: onyourtoes

children.name: Someone or something that keeps you on your toes forces you to continue directing all your attention and energy to what you are doing
examples: I work with people who are half my age so thatkeepsme on my toes.

children.name: responsive
children.definition: reacting quickly, in a positive way :
examples: a car withhighly responsivesteering
responsive to
She wasn't responsivetoquestioning.
We try to be responsive to the needs of the customer.
Her condition is not responsive to drug therapy.
responsivelyadverb
responsiveness[U]
